questions:
You are a junior doctor working in anaesthetics. You are being mentored by a male middle grade doctor and are feeling uncomfortable with the way he speaks to you at work. He is overly familiar, often flirtatious and makes unwelcome sexual comments, excusing them as 'just a joke'. You are concerned he might try to go further, and about what other people might think. What do you do?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
The GMC always advises to try to resolve conflicts with the person in question in the first instance. It is quite possible that this doctor has not realised that he is making you feel uncomfortable and simply flagging it up to him may end things. If you keep a record of exactly what has happened and when, should things not get resolved you have your evidence. Simply accepting it as 'banter' is not right - things may escalate. Informing those higher up would occur if it is not resolved in the first instance.

title: GMC: Good medical practice - Communication, partnership and teamwork
body:
Communication, partnership and teamwork form one of the four domains listed in the Good Medical Practice. This domain focuses on the standards expected of doctors in areas such as communication and collaboration with patients and colleagues.

Effective communication
  • Listen to patients and answer any questions honestly
  • Ensure that information is delivered in a manner that can be understood. Identify and apply practical measures to overcome any communication and language barriers
  • Provide support and information to patients' relatives or carers in a considerate manner
  • Doctors on duty need to be easily reachable by their patients and colleagues for any advice or support

Partnership with patients
  • Empower patients with the information required for patients to make decisions with regards to their care. This includes information on the clinical conditions, treatment options and the relevant risks and uncertainties
  • Ensure that patients are aware of the progress of their care
  • The roles and responsibilities of each member of the team need to be made clear to the patients
  • Patient confidentiality needs to be maintained, even after the patient is deceased

Fair and respectful care of all patients
  • Respect patients' dignity and privacy
  • Respect any health, cultural and religious beliefs held by the patients, even if they do not agree with yours.

If you have a conscientious objection to a particular procedure e.g. abortion, you need to:
  • Inform the patient that they have the right to see another practitioner
  • Provide the necessary information and support towards the patient seeking another doctor. In doing so, refrain from expressing disapproval of the patient's lifestyle, choices or beliefs
  • Find another doctor to substitute you if it is not practical for the patient to arrange to see another doctor

Partnership with colleagues
  • Doctors are expected to work in a team in a manner that serves patients' best interest
  • It is important to respect the skills and contributions of every member of the team and be fair to every member of the team
  • Understand that your actions may affect others within and outside the team
  • It is your duty to complete any post that you have formally accepted as leaving the post assigned to you may compromise patient safety especially if this creates a gap in the medical rota
  • Unless the trust has a reasonable time to make adjustments, it is important that you work the hours required of your contract before leaving a job

Coordination of care between healthcare providers and between health and social care providers. This include
  • Providing all relevant information to all clinicians or social care providers involved in the care of the patients
  • Checking that a named doctor or team has taken over the care
  • Ensure that the clinician filling in for you or taking over the care is appropriately trained to provide safe care for the patient

The Good Medical Practice also made statements with regards to Doctors as teachers. It recommends that doctors support the training and teaching of junior staff members and medical students*. This includes
  • Ensuring adequate supervision
  • Writing honest feedback/references/appraisals on their competence, performance and conduct
  • Being a mentor
  • Supporting those who are struggling with their performance or health

*In all circumstances, patient safety needs to be prioritised

options: Use a telephone translation service to get the history
Use his daughter to act as an interpreter
Use diagrams and body language to elicit the history
Use 'Google Translate', taking it in turns to enter the text
Arrange an appointment as soon as you can get an interpreter
questions:
A 45-year-old Polish man comes in to surgery with his 19-year-old daughter. She describes him becoming increasingly withdrawn over the past few weeks and is worried he may be depressed. He speaks very limited English but his daughter is fluent.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This scenario is increasingly common in the UK due to migration patterns of the past decade.

The best response is to use the telephone translation service as this will allow you to quickly get some idea of this man's problems, for example, if he had any suicidal ideation. Waiting for an interpreter to come into surgery may take a number of days and is, therefore, the second-best option.

Using his daughter is a poor option as his depression may relate to family problems.

Computer translation services such as Google Translate are not sufficiently accurate to ensure the nuances of his symptoms are understood

Diagrams and body language will not adequately elicit a depression history.

questions:
You are a ST1 doctor in cardiology. You have been signed-off to perform central lines by yourself. Whilst attempting to insert an internal jugular central line you accidentally flush the line with around 1 ml of air. The patient suffers no apparent adverse effects.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Luckily the patient appears not to have come to harm from the error. Despite this it is important to be open and handle the situation as you would for any other error. The consultant in charge of the patients care should be notified in case he/she wants to take any further action. The patient should be given an explanation and apology. Following this a clinical incident form should be completed. This allows frequent errors to be recognised so that systems may be changed.

Adding a reflective entry to your e-portfolio is better than doing nothing but does not tackle the immediate situation.

Taking no action is a poor option as it does not address any of the issues.

options: Respect his wishes and book a follow-up appointment for four weeks
Arrange a CT head and check bloods to exclude cerebral metastases and hypercalcaemia
Arrange an appointment with a psychiatrist
Discuss his reasons for not wanting treatment in more detail
Speak to his wife alone to find out why he is refusing surgery
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor in medicine. A 67-year-old man has been investigated for anaemia and weight loss. Endoscopy shows a gastric tumour which is confirmed as an adenocarcinoma on biopsy. On discussing the diagnosis the patient states that he has had 'a good life' and doesn't want any treatment. Clinical examination is unremarkable. He is able to retain and understand the information you give to him, including the likely curative nature of surgery.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This question is ultimately about autonomy. By being able to understand and retain the information you give him the patient has demonstrated that he is competent to make decisions. It should be noted that the Mental Capacity Act 2005 states that 'a person is not to be treated as unable to make a decision merely because he makes an unwise decision'.

Exploring his reasons for not wanting surgery is the best option - you may be able to clear up so misunderstandings. This, of course, should be information giving, rather than 'persuading' - the patient has the autonomy to make their own decision.

A CT head and bloods may exclude causes that would impair judgement but would you override his decision even if you noticed evidence of a cerebral metastase? As there is no evidence that this man is suffering from a mental illness referral to a psychiatrist would be inappropriate.

By speaking to the wife alone you are risking breaching confidentiality. Detaining him under the Mental Health Act simply because you disagree with his decision is clearly wrong.

options: Remind your colleague that doctors cannot engage in non-professional loving relationships with patients
Ask for advice from your supervisor
Follow the trust policy on raising concerns regarding inappropriate relationships with patients
Ensure that the patient has capacity before allowing them to continue
Call 999 and inform the police
Tell your other colleagues about what you have seen to ask them how they would respond to the situation
Inform the patient's family of the situation
Move the patient to a different ward
Report your colleague directly to the GMC
Talk about the situation loudly at the nurses station, so that someone will overhear and act on the situation
questions:
Whilst working on the cardiology ward, you notice your colleague repeatedly visiting one of the patients in a side room. They appear to be laughing together and acting intimately with one another. Later that day, you overhear him making inappropriate sexual comments towards her. When you ask your colleague about it, he discloses that he feels he has found a true connection with her and they are planning to go on a date after her discharge.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
Inappropriate and unprofessional sexual comments are considered to be sexual behaviours. If you are able to, you should remind your colleague of this and inform them that you will be following your trust policy. You may wish to ask for advice from a supervisor on how to handle this complex scenario.

It would be inappropriate to assess the patient's capacity as this is irrelevant here. Patient care and safety must be protected.

It would be an overreaction to contact the police and a waste of their time unless you believe an individual to be in imminent danger.

Telling other colleagues would likely be seen as gossip, and involves disclosing information to those who do not need to know.

Similarly, informing the patient's family could be a breach of confidentiality and is an unnecessary action.

Moving the patient to a different ward ignores the issue at hand. It is unlikely to change the situation and could confuse the patient. It may also jeopardise the quality of care they receive.

Reporting your colleague directly to the GMC would be an inappropriate escalation at this point. You may consider contacting the GMC to investigate only if you feel the response within your trust to the incident has been inadequate.

Talking loudly at the nurse's station would be very unprofessional. This could lead to multiple staff members, patients and family members overhearing private information.

title: GMC: Sexual behaviour and your duty to report colleagues
body:
Actions that may be considered to be sexual behaviours:
  • Physical contact that is neither appropriate nor necessary for the care of a patient
  • Unprofessional and inappropriate sexual remarks

The Good Medical Practice has stated that doctors should not make any sexual advances or engage in a non-professional loving relationship with a patient or anyone close to them. Failure to abide by this may jeopardise patient care and the public trust in doctors. This may also lead to deregistration.

If you find that your colleague has engaged in a verbal or non-verbal sexual behaviour with a patient, you have a duty to report this because patient safety or care may be compromised. This should be done according to the GMC guidance on raising concerns as such:
  • Follow the trust policy if available
  • Ask advice from a senior e.g. direct supervisor, consultant, clinical director, GP partner
  • If you work in a general practice, seek advice from the GP partner. However, if the incident involves the partner, raise your concern outside the practice e.g. clinical governance lead.
  • Contact the General Medical Council to investigate if you feel that the response to the incident has been inadequate

When reporting this matter, only disclose pertinent details. Patient identity should be concealed unless patient safety becomes an issue (i.e. patient safety trumps patient confidentiality. Prior to breaking confidentiality, patient's consent should be obtained. If the patient declines to consent, the disclosure is only appropriate if it is in the public interest.

In the case of a sexual assault or a criminal activity such as rape or engaging in sexual intercourse with an underage patient, the police should be involved. In cases involving children, safeguarding team should be involved.

options: Thank the patient and suggest that a small donation to the ward would be sufficient
Accept the gift and tell the patient not to tell anyone else
Thank them but politely decline the gift
Walk out of the room and decline to care for the patient any longer
Explain your reasons for declining the gift
Thank them and accept the gift
Accept the gift and suggest to the patient that they should also get a gift for the ward staff
Reassure the patient that their care will not be affected by you declining the gift
questions:
A patient that you have been looking after for the past 2 weeks gives you a £200 Amazon gift card for caring for them.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
This is a tricky scenario. Patients often show their gratitude by buying gifts for members of staff that have been involved in their care. As a general rule, something that is small and can be shared amongst the ward staff such as a box of chocolates is acceptable. Money, on the other hand, is unacceptable. The GMC guidelines state that 'You must not ask for or accept from patients, colleagues or others any inducement, gift or hospitality that may affect or be seen to affect the way you prescribe for, treat or refer patients or commission services for patients.' Therefore, you should thank the patient and politely decline the gift (option 3). Explain your reasons for declining the gift so the patient is not offended (option 5) and reassure the patient that their care will not be affected by you declining their gift (option 8).

Options 1 and 7 may be seen as putting undue pressure on the patient by suggesting that they also need to get something for the ward staff. Options 2 and 6 are not acceptable as this is a gift of high monetary value. Therefore, you should not accept it, neither should you attempt to conceal it.

options: Politely decline the money and explain why you cannot accept it
Ask the patient if she is sure, and keep the money to treat yourself with when she says yes
Keep the money but donate it to charity yourself
Say thank you very much, and keep the money
Ask the patient to donate the money to charity instead
questions:
You are a GP trainee. An elderly patient is successfully treated for colorectal cancer after you referred her for investigations. She gives you a card to say thank you for caring for her. In the card is £100 and a card saying, 'Thanks for everything, treat yourself.'

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This question covers the Good Medical Practice Domain, 'Maintaining Trust - Honesty in Financial Dealings.' This states that you must not accept gifts from patients which may be seen to affect the way that you treat a patient.

Doctors should not accept large gifts from patients. The best option is therefore to explain this to the patient, and politely decline the gift. An alternative to this if the patient insists on giving you a gift, is to ask them to donate the money to charity themselves. Keeping the money yourself is not advised, but donating it a charity yourself is morally a better option than keeping it. Checking that the patient is sure that you can keep the money before accepting it is almost as unwise as accepting it without question, which is the worst option.

GMC, Good Medical Practice, 2014, Paragraph 80.

options: Ask the patient to attend in-house clinical photography
Enquire whether community clinical photography would be available for photography
Ensure any photographs obscure or avoid his tattoo
Focus on finishing the consultation before revisiting the possibility of photographing the lesion
Make sure a copy of the photograph is inputted into his GP records
Perform a full capacity assessment on the patient before deciding on taking photographs
Post the photo as an anonymised submission in your educational resource page from your phone
Take a photograph on your phone and ensure it is deleted fully as soon as the photo is uploaded
Tell him there is no way the photographs can be taken securely
questions:
You attend a home visit for a 67-year-old man complaining of abdominal pain. He has severe mobility issues.

On examination, you notice an erythematous, vesicular rash on his right elbow next to a tattoo. He mentions he has poorly controlled coeliac disease.

You diagnose this as the rare clinical sign of dermatitis herpetiformis. Coincidentally, you are compiling a visual learning resource on a Facebook page and mention an interest in photographing the lesion. The patient encourages you to photograph his rash.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
Focus on finishing the consultation before revisiting the possibility of photographing the lesion. Firstly, it is important to finish the consultation before moving on to the possibility of photography. The visual bank you are creating is a personal project, but the home visit consultation is your duty as a healthcare professional. It can be addressed as an aside once his presenting complaint has been managed.

Enquire whether community clinical photography would be available for photography. It may be possible for clinical photography to get involved as there is a role for community-based clinical photography because of cases like this where the patient has poor mobility. As this is a personal project, they may well refuse. It is worth asking, however, as this sign is rare and it would be educationally valuable.

Ensure any photographs obscure or avoid his tattoo. Tattoos are identifiable features of a person, and so it is good practice to obscure them if possible (as is commonly done with eyes). As this sign is next to his tattoo, this won't affect the educational value of the photograph. This helps to maintain the anonymity of the patient.

Ask the patient to attend in-house clinical photography. It is inappropriate to ask the patient to attend clinical photography as he has very poor mobility and may feel pressured to attend despite facing difficulty doing so. Making a reasonable adjustment for the patient's condition would be a more professional and kinder alternative.

Make sure a copy of the photograph is inputted into his GP records. While his abdominal pain may be related to his poorly controlled coeliac disease, it is unnecessary to have a copy in the GP notes unless they are being sent to a specialist for review due to uncertainty of origin. Sometimes this may be appropriate (for example, suspicious bruises in suspected child abuse), but this is not such a time. Furthermore, it can much more easily be described.

Perform a full capacity assessment on the patient before deciding on taking photographs. It is inappropriate to perform a capacity assessment as there is no indication he lacks capacity. For example, there is no history of dementia or delirium, common cases where capacity may need to be assessed.

Post the photo as an anonymised submission in your educational resource page from your phone. It is inappropriate to take photos from your phone and clinical photography should be contacted to take these photos as they may not be stored with adequate security or disposed of correctly.

Take a photograph on your phone and ensure it is deleted fully as soon as the photo is uploaded. It is inappropriate to take photographs yourself. These photographs can easily be forgotten and not deleted. Furthermore, it is wrong to post them yourself from your phone; often, the location is embedded and uploaded with the photograph on social media. It is important to be aware of this, as it could compromise the confidentiality of the patient by giving away his address.

Tell him there is no way the photographs can be taken securely. While this is an option, it would be a shame not to input a photo of a rare sign in your project unless clinical photography or the patient objects. As community clinical photography is an option, this is technically not true and it is an option if they consent (which needs to be checked).

title: GMC: Doctors' use of social media
body:
The guidance published by the GMC on social media usage is broad in its scope: the emphasis is on upholding the same professional standards as we do with our face-to-face interactions and those on traditional media. These notes are not intended to act as a substitute the full guidance, but rather to provide an accessible summary of salient points for revision purposes.

The GMC definition of 'social media' makes reference to blogs (including Twitter), internet forums, content communities (such as Youtube and Instagram) and social networking sites (such as Facebook and LinkedIn). In case studies published on the GMC website, the scope is also widened to include group messaging services (such as WhatsApp).

When using social media, it is important to remember the following:
  • Social media sites cannot guarantee privacy regardless of what privacy settings are in place
  • As such, it should be assumed that patients, employers (current and prospective), professional regulators can see your personal information
  • Once information has been published online it can be difficult or impossible to erase completely
  • Information about your location may also be embedded within photographs and may be shared without your knowledge
  • Content posted anonymously can be traced back to its point of origin in many cases

Practical recommendations included within the guidance:
  • Maintain privacy: regularly review privacy settings, ensure all content published is only accessible to the intended audience.
  • Maintain boundaries: do not communicate with patients via personal profiles such as Facebook. Instead redirect them to the relevant professional channels if appropriate.
  • Maintain confidentiality: never share identifiable patient information online, even in forums accessible by 'professionals' only. Remember: the sum of information available online may enable identification, even if the individual was not identifiable from your post or entry in isolation.
  • Maintain respect for colleagues: treat colleagues fairly and with respect ( Good Medical Practice). Never bully, harass or make unfounded claims. Defamation and copyright law still applies when referring to an individual organisation online even when using a personal profile.
  • Maintain trust in the profession: if you identify yourself as a doctor, you must also identify by your name, and ensure any content published in this capacity is factual and can be cross-checked. Be open about conflicts of interest.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The best option is to interrupt immediately (B). Interrupting immediately would prevent further discussion, and potentially prevent confidential informnextation from being shared.

The next best option is to speak to the individuals later (E).

Your educational supervisor will be able to provide you with advice and help you decide on what action to take (D).

A worse option would be to do nothing and allow this practice, which could take place in less discrete environments, to continue (A).

Going straight to social media is unprofessional and against GMC guidelines (C).

options: Give her details of a domestic violence support group
Refer her son to the Children and Adolescent Mental Health Service
Contact the local Child Protection Officer
Phone her partner after surgery and make it clear such behaviour must stop
Advise her to attend self-defence classes
Make a note to offer an anger management course to the partner the next time you see him
Make a follow-up appointment for next week
Explore why she is making her partner so angry
questions:
A 23-year-old woman comes in with depression. Immediately you notice bruising on the left side of her face. She tells you her partner got angry as her 3-year-old boy threw his food on the floor during a family meal. When she told him not to shout at her son her partner slapped her across the face. The patient describes her son as having 'too much energy'. Her partner has never harmed, or threaten to harm, her son and she does not want police involvement.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
Domestic violence witnessed by a child is now classified as a form of abuse. It is therefore appropriate to contact the local Child Protection Officer. A domestic violence support group may be able to offer her practical advice and arrange a possible refuge. Making a follow-up appointment is good practice as it allows you to assess progress.

Referring her son to the Children and Adolescent Mental Health Service implies this is the root cause of the problems, rather that her partners violence. It is normal for 3-year-olds to be full of energy and referral is not necessary at this point. Whilst it may be argued that self-defence classes offer practical help it does not address the root cause and may lead to an escalation of violence.

Discussing this with her partner both breaks confidentiality and also puts the patient at risk from retribution.
